captions.text:
The geographic midpoint of the European Union
is a big deal — apparently.
It’s not quite where you’d expect it:
if you were to make a map of the EU on cardboard,
it would be the centre of gravity.
Until 31st June this year,

the centre was in a field just outside of Meerholz
in the municipality of Gelnhausen
in the German state of Hesse.

But then Croatia became
a full member of the European Union,

and the centre moved
to the village of Westerngrund

just inside Bavaria, and just
a couple of miles from where I live.

It took a month to organise
an appropriate festival,

but on 31st July 2013,
half the residents of Westerngrund turned out,
along with lots of people from the press.
After much fevered anticipation,

the assembled guests tried to remember
the words of the Bavarian State Anthem...

...the mayor of Westerngrund formally welcomed
the guests and made a speech...

...and then the special guest,
Bavaria’s finance minister, made a speech...
...before unveiling a special plaque.

Then the mayor of Gelnhausen assured everybody
he wasn’t upset at losing this special status...

...and finally the mayor of Westerngrund was
presented with dirt from the other EU countries...
...and the finance minister with a packed lunch.

And then it was off
to the exact centre of the European Union.

There, to the sounds of the EU National Anthem
and a dodgy PA system,
the EU flag was solemnly raised.
Then the children released their balloons...

...and everybody made their way back
for beer and cake,

aglow in the knowledge that,
at least for the next few years,

little Westerngrund is more
than an obscure community
hidden in the rolling hills of Lower Franconia.

title: Journey to the Centre of the EU
